quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
>>> x = 4
>>> x *= 3
>>> print(x)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]In-Place Operators[/h1]

[b]In-place operators[/b] allow you to write code like 'x = x + 3' more concisely, as 'x += 3'. 
The same thing is possible with other operators such as [b]-, *, / [/b]and [b]%[/b] as well. [code format="py" codeId="291"]>>> x = 2
>>> print(x)
2
>>> x += 3
>>> print(x)
5[/code]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
>>> x = "a"
>>> x *= 3
print(x)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]In-Place Operators[/h1]

These operators can be used on types other than numbers, as well, such as [b]strings[/b].[code format="py" codeId="292"]>>> x = "spam"
>>> print(x)
spam

>>> x += "eggs"
>>> print(x)
spameggs[/code]
[note]Many other languages have special operators such as '++' as a shortcut for 'x += 1'. Python[b] does not [/b]have these.[/note]
